questions.question:
Question 1: A 9-year-old child infected with Toxocara canis is diagnosed to have visceral larva migrans. It 
is an example of 
.
questions.explanation:
494 
Sold by @itachibot Toxocara canis (dog roundworm) infecting a human is an example of an aberrant parasite. It is 
defined as a parasite that infects a host where they cannot develop further. Parasites can be classified as: • Ectoparasites - inhabit only the body surface of the host without penetrating the tissue. The term 
infestation is often used for parasitization. e.g., lice, ticks, and mites. • Endoparasite - lives within the body of the host and causes infection. Endoparasites are further classified as follows: • Obligate parasites - cannot exist without a host. e.g., Toxoplasma gondii and Plasmodium. • Facultative parasites - exist as either parasitic or free-living forms. e.g., Naegleria fowleri. • Accidental parasites - infects an unusual host. e.g., Echinococcus granulosus infects man • Aberrant/Wandering parasites - infects a host where they cannot develop further. e.g., Toxocara 
canis (dog roundworm) infecting humans.

questions.question:
Question 2: Which of the following refers to a host in which the larval stage of the parasite remains viable 
without further development?
questions.explanation:
A host in which the larval stage of the parasite remains viable without further development is 
referred to as the paratenic host. For example, in the lifecycle of Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm), humans are the 
definitive host. The first intermediate host is cyclops and the second is small freshwater fish. If the 
small freshwater fish with the plerocercoid larva get eaten by a larger fish, the larva survives in the 
larger fish. This makes the larger fish a paratenic host. Host is an organism that harbors the parasite and provides nourishment and shelter to it. It is 
relatively larger than the parasite. Types of hosts: • Definitive host - harbors stages of sexual reproduction of the parasite. • Intermediate host - harbors stages of asexual multiplication of the parasite. • Paratenic host - harbors only the larval stage of the parasite which remains viable without 
further development. • Reservoir host - harbors the parasite and acts as an important source of infection to other 
susceptible hosts, especially in endemic areas. • Accidental host - harbors a parasite that is not usually found in the host.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 46-year-old farmer came to the clinic with cough and chest pain for one week and fatigue 
for a month. He was diagnosed to have a hydatid cyst in his right lung. Which of the following 
classes does the causative organism of this disease belong to?
questions.explanation:
The causative organism of hydatid disease is Echinococcus granulosus and it belongs to the 
class cestodes. It is a tape-like, segmented worm. It infects man accidentally, giving rise to hydatid cysts. 495 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows the classification of parasites. Note: Zoonoses refers to diseases caused by zoonotic organisms. It is not a class of organisms.

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following is the smallest cestode infecting humans? 489 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: The smallest cestode infecting humans is Hymenolepis nana. Option A: Diphyllobothrium latum is the longest cestode infecting man. Option C: Heterophyes heterophyes is the smallest trematode infecting man. Option D: Strongyloides stercoralis is the smallest nematode infecting man. Also, Fasciolopsis buski is the largest trematode infecting humans.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following parasites has a direct life cycle?
questions.explanation:
Enterobius vermicularis has a direct life cycle. Parasite requiring a single host to complete its development is said to have a direct life cycle. Parasites having a direct life cycle are: Parasite requiring two or more hosts to complete its development is said to have indirect life 
cycle, e.g. Plasmodium spp. 496

questions.question: Question 6: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
The correct answer is option B. A boy from Kolkata with fever and massive splenomegaly is likely suffering from Kala-azar caused 
by Leishmania donovani. Its intermediate host is sandfly. A lady from Kerala with bilateral non-pitting pedal edema is likely suffering from lymphatic 
filariasis caused by Wuchereria bancrofti. Its intermediate host is the culex mosquito. 497 
Sold by @itachibot A man presenting with new-onset seizures and MRI brain showing cyst with a dot sign is likely 
suffering from neurocysticercosis caused by ingestion of Taenia solium eggs (Cysticercus 
cellulose). The intermediate host of Taenia Solium is the pig. A woman having fever with her peripheral smear showing Maltese cross appearance is likely 
suffering from babesiosis caused by Babesia microti. Its intermediate host is human. 498 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: An entomologist who had recently visited Mexico presented to the OPD with fever, fatigue, 
and an alleged history of contact with the insect given in the image. Which of the following 
diseases is it a biological vector for? 490 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows reduviid bug which is the biological vector for the transmission of 
Chagas disease. Acute Chagas disease can present as fever with fatigue and a subcutaneous 
swelling known as a chagoma. It may lead to fatal myocarditis. Biological vectors not only help in the transfer of parasites but the parasites undergo development 
or multiplication in their body as well. They are also called true vectors. Examples of biological vectors are: • Mosquito - Malaria, filariasis • Sandfly - Kala-azar • Tsetse fly - Sleeping sickness • Reduviid bugs - Chagas disease • Ticks - Babesiosis

questions.question: Question 8: Autoinfection is not seen with which of the following parasites?
questions.explanation:
Autoinfection is not seen in infection with Ascaris lumbricoides. Autoinfection refers to either of the following: • Reinfection by microbes or parasitic organisms that are present on or within the body. It is also 
known as internal reinfection. e.g., Strongyloides. • Self-infection by direct contact with a contagious agent, as with parasite eggs in the infectious 
state transmitted by fingernails. e.g., Pinworm. The following are the parasites causing autoinfection (mnemonic: CHEST.C) 499 
Sold by @itachibot • Cryptosporidium parvum • Hymenolepis nana • Enterobius vermicularis • Strongyloides stercoralis • Taenia solium • Capillaria philippinensis.

questions.question:
Question 9: A microbiologist is doing research about antigenic variations in parasites. Which of the 
following parasites will exhibit this phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Trypanosoma brucei exhibits antigenic variation within the host. This genetic switch protects 
them from antibodies. These trypanosomes exhibit unique antigenic variations of their glycoproteins. There is a cyclical 
fluctuation in the trypanosomes occurring in the blood of infected vertebrates after every 7–10 
days. Parasites exhibiting antigenic variation include: • Trypanosoma brucei gambiense • Trypanosome brucei rhodesiense • Plasmodium spp. • Giardia lamblia The following image shows Trypanosoma brucei. The following image shows Plasmodium spp. 500 
Sold by @itachibot The following image shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia.

questions.question:
Question 10: You order a peripheral blood film examination while evaluating a patient with pyrexia of 
unknown origin. Which of the following organisms cannot be detected by this investigation?
questions.explanation:
Stool examination is useful for the detection of Giardia lamblia, not peripheral blood film 
examination. Examination of blood is of vital importance for demonstrating parasites that circulate in blood 
vessels. Examples of parasites found in the peripheral blood film: 501 
Sold by @itachibot Protozoa 
Nematodes Plasmodium spp.Babesia spp.

questions.question:
Question 11: A Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear is prepared. Which of the following cannot be 
diagnosed?
questions.explanation:
The diagnosis of Coxiella burnetii cannot be done using a Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear. It is done mainly by serology, which shows a rise in the titer of specific antibodies to C. burnetii. Microorganisms such as Histoplasma, Leishmania, Toxoplasma, and Pneumocystis can also be 
detected with Giemsa, and in gastric tissues, Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) appear thin and 
distinctly blue. Giemsa’s stain is frequently used for diagnostic purposes in haematology to 
differentiate the nuclear and cytoplasmic morphology of platelets, RBCs, WBCs, and parasites.

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient has presented to the PHC with fever and chills. You order a rapid diagnostic test to 
detect HRP-2 antigen. Which of the following diseases is it used to diagnose?
questions.explanation: HRP-2 antigen detection is used in the diagnosis of malaria. Malaria antigens detected by the rapid immunochromatographic test are: • pLDH - positivity is seen in all Plasmodium species • HRP-2 - positivity is specific for P. falciparum The below image shows rapid diagnostic test (RDT) kit for malaria.

questions.question:
Question 13: In a patient with a positive Casoni's skin test, which of the following infections will you 
suspect?
questions.explanation:
502 
Sold by @itachibot Casoni’s skin test is done in patients with hydatid disease. It is an immediate hypersensitivity reaction (type I). This test is abandoned now due to non-specificity and has been supplemented by serological tests.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient presented to the OPD with cough, chest pain, and expectoration of rusty colored 
sputum. He is diagnosed to have an oriental lung fluke infection. Which of the following 
parasites is implicated here?
questions.explanation:
Paragonimus westermani is commonly known as oriental lung fluke or Japanese lung fluke. It 
causes a pulmonary syndrome characterised by cough, chest pain and hemoptysis. Paragonimus westermani is a trematode. The transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or 
undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The metacercariae excyst in the human 
gut and young worms migrate to the lungs, where they become encapsulated in lung tissue. The patient complains of cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. The viscous sputum is speckled with 
golden-brown eggs. Treatment: Praziquantel (25 mg/ kg TDS for 1-2 days) is the drug of choice. The following image shows the life cycle of Paragonimus westermani, the oriental lung fluke.

questions.question:
Question 15: A college student from Mangalore comes to the OPD with intermittent fever, headache, and 
chills for 1 week. She gives a history of malaria 1 year back for which she had received 
treatment. Which of the following species you would expect to see in the peripheral smear of 
this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of malaria relapse and it is caused by Plasmodium vivax 
and Plasmodium ovale species. In case of P.vivax and P.ovale, two kinds of sporozoites are seen. Some multiply inside hepatic 
cells to form schizonts while others persist and remain dormant as hypnozoites (resting forms). 
These dormant forms may get activated and release merozoites, which go on infecting RBCs 
producing true clinical relapse. It usually occurs after 6 to 12 months of complete cure from the 
disease. 503 
Sold by @itachibot In case of P.falciparum and P.malariae, the initial tissue phase disappears completely and no 
hypnozoites are found, hence relapse is not seen. In Plasmodium falciparum, recrudescence can be seen which is defined as the recurrence of 
asexual parasitemia. It usually occurs within 8 weeks of treatment and is due to incomplete 
treatment or drug resistance.

questions.question:
Question 16: A middle-aged woman comes to the clinic with abdominal pain, diarrhea, fatigue, and weight 
loss. Stool examination revealed bile-stained eggs. Which of the following organisms may not 
be implicated in this case?
questions.explanation:
Enterobius vermicularis eggs are non-bile stained and the others are bile stained. Enterobiasis commonly occurs in young children and is characterised by anal pruritus. The 
worm may migrate up to the uterus, fallopian tubes and into the peritoneum in adult women. This 
can lead to: • Chronic salpingitis • Cervicitis • Peritonitis • Recurrent urinary tract infections.

questions.question:
Question 17: 493 
Sold by @itachibot You are examining a wet mount stool sample of a patient with diarrhea. As the eggs are not 
visible, you concentrate the sample using the saturated salt solution technique. Which of the 
following eggs will not float in this technique?
questions.explanation:
The eggs of Strongyloides stercoralis will not float in a saturated salt solution. Concentration methods are used when the parasites in stool are scanty and difficult to identify in 
routine stool examination. It is of 2 types: • Floatation methods- the feces are suspended in a solution of high specific gravity and eggs will 
float up. e.g. saturated salt solution technique, zinc sulfate centrifugal floatation technique. • Sedimentation Methods - the feces are suspended in a solution with low specific gravity and eggs 
will sediment at the bottom. e.g. formol-ether sedimentation technique. 504 
Sold by @itachibot Protozoology - Amoebae, Ciliates & Flagellates
